articles.title: Reproducible science XTBG 2022
articles.description: A four-day workshop on reproducible science
articles.contents:
Basic info
Who: G.G.O Dossa
When: 9am-5:30 pm every day from June 27-30, 2022
Where: XTBG
Workshop introduction
The following is the tentative outline of a two day workshop that
will be held in Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden (XTBG) from June 27-30
2022. The purpose of this workshop is to get participants
familiar with the concept of reproducible
science that is surprisingly not commonly taught but which
is becoming a requirement for better collaboration (not only with others
but with oneself through time) and for credible science. At the end of
this workshop, attendees should be familiar with tools use to achieve
reproducible science, will be more confident with themselves, and be
inclined to adopt these tools which will ease their collaboration with
themselves as well as others. This course consists of four main parts
which aim to putting everything from data to final report including r
code and some interpretations and also exercises as step by step work me
through method. This course will be mainly taught by Dossa G.G.O. click here to email me. Dossa
teaches this section yearly at the postgraduate Advanced Fieldcourse in
Ecology and Conservation – XTBG AFEC-X for the past two
years.
Who should attend this course?
Anyone who carries out research either as student, or research staff
and seeks guidance to manage data efficiently, to improve peers
credibility in their research output, and is keen to make science solid
and credible. Consider thinking about the following questions:
Have you ever worked collaboratively with others, and received
multiple comments that you needed to deal with?
Have you been ever asked by your collaborators/supervisor to go back
to previous version of your manuscripts/analysis/ results?
Have you ever thought that you finalized an analysis but to realize
a mistake was in the data file?
Have you ever spent endless time to explain your past / current
projects to your collaborators (including yourself) but realize you even
do not remember what you did at some point or why you did certain
things?
Have you ever copied a table from R/SPSS/Minitab/SAS to excel, and
subsequently from Excel to your word processing document? And most
annoyingly, you need to repeat these steps whenever anything has changed
in the analysis or code.
Timeline
Module 1: Motivations and intro [Module1]]
Module 2: Bridging the gap among actors| video] [Module2 |
video]
Module 3: Dealing with data analysis in the tidyverse
[Module3 | Exercise | solutions | video]
Module 4: Dealing with data analysis in the tidyverse
using ggplot2 [Module4 | Exercise | solutions | video]
Module 5: Literate statistical programming: knitr [Module5 | Exercise | solutions
| video]
Module 6: R Markdown [Module6 | practical | solutions | video]
Module 7: Version control Git and Github [Module7 |
practical | solutions | video]
Module 8: Extra class on git and Github [Module7_extra | practical | solutions
| video]
Module 9: R project [Module | practical | video]
Module 10: Reproducible: Good enough workflow [Module
| video]
Module 11: Extras (Writing article in R markdown, Quarto (If time
permits)) [Module | video]
Requirements
Attendees are required to install the following software
beforehand
1- Git
2- Create a Github account on
3- Download a Github
desktop
4- Download and install
R
5- Download
RStudio
6- Have Git, GitHub and RStudio talk to each other following these
guidelines (section 2.2.2 Configuration only).
7- Install the following R packages:
tidyverse, sf, emo,
janitor, palmerpenguins, usethis
and lubridate. You can install them all at once by running
the following code in the R command line:


install.packages(c("tidyverse", "sf", "emo", "janitor", "palmerpenguins", "usethis", "lubridate"))



Below are books you can read at your spare time not required to read
before the course.
8- Book about
Github
9- Ggplot2 second edition
10- R
Markdown book
Also kindly read the two following documents prior to start of the
workshop: (i) Five
selfish reasons and (ii) Reproducible
code.
Corrections
If you see mistakes or want to suggest changes, please create
an issue on the source repository.
